AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: a medium-sized, deciduous conifer having delicate, soft, green foliage and golden fall color
flat needles ¾-1” long found in clusters of 15-25 on dwarf twigs
thin, smooth and gray when young, becoming red-brown with age
male flowers are small and yellow; female flowers are red-brown
small, egg-shaped cone, red at flowering, chestnut brown with age, persist throughout winter

The Tamarack or American Larch is one of three deciduous conifers growing on WSU campus grounds. The other deciduous conifers, the Dawn Redwood and the Baldcypress, are introduced species; the Tamarack is native to Minnesota. The Tamarack’s native range stretches from Minnesota to West Virginia and northward throughout Canada. The name, Tamarack, was given to the tree by the Algonquin American Indians. This small-to medium-sized tree is best known for its soft, light green needles and brilliant golden-yellow fall color. It has a pyramidal, open shape with slender, pendulous branches. The Tamarack is extremely cold tolerant, able to survive temperatures down to 85 below zero Fahrenheit. The Tamarack’s native habitat is boggy wetlands, but it can grow well on drier sites. It is intolerant of shade. Due to its shallow root system, the tree can be sensitive to drought. The most serious pest is the Larch sawfly. The Tamarack or Larch is occasionally used in landscaping, but the Japanese or European Larch has better features for a landscaping tree. This is especially true when used for a bonsai or weeping form of the tree. The Tamarack tree has a deep, rich association with Native Americans. Algonquin Indians used the wood for snowshoes. The Ojibwa used the roots for sewing edges of canoes. Other Native Americans used the dried, hardened Tamarack for making shelters and tools. The Cree used the inner bark as a medical remedy for a number of ailments. Today, Tamarack is not a major commercial timber, but it is used for pulpwood. Since the wood is decay-resistant and durable, it is often used for utility poles, posts and railroad ties. At WSU, a small Tamarack collection can be found directly north of Minné Hall. This site was selected due to soil conditions that mimic a bog or swamp. At this site, three Tamaracks can be found. The trees on the far left and far right are Tamarack or American Larch, while the tree in the middle is a Japanese version of this tree. At WSU, the Japanese Tamarack has a more graceful appearance, a stronger green color, and a more vigorous and healthy appearance.
